results.title: Violence is Violence
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, SKA TV and Campbell Manderson
results.brief_description: A report on the concerns over the private toll road which was built at the expense of over 2 hectares of public parkland in inner Sydney. Hundreds of Sydney residents take over the streets to protest car-dominated public space and offer a vision of urban sustainability. Their celebration is met with a brutal police response. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Ordinary extraordinary stories
results.brief_description: Ordinary Extraordinary stories features a selection of digital stories produced as part of ACMI digital storytelling public workshop program. This collection celebrates the extraordinary stories of ordinary people. The stories are as diverse as the people who have created them

results.title: The Great Sea Explorer
results.brief_description:
The story of Matthew Flinders and his journey to Australia. After leaving his family in England, Flinders sets off to sea, and after many years travelling to and around Australia, he returns home. His heroic journey is rewarded by the Queen with a house as a gift for his exploration achievements.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: A Day in the Life of Captain Cook
results.brief_description:
A reenactment of Captain Cook and his crew hitting land after a treacherous arrival to a new island, later named Botany Bay.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: The Memory of Water (part 1)
results.credit_line: Video excerpt and still images on this page are provided courtesy of the artist.
results.brief_description:
The ‘Memory of Water (part 1)’ explores Carl Jung’s notion of the ‘collective unconscious’, examining consciousness in the form of memory or perceived experience and the power of the gaze as that which mediates external phenomena. Sadia’s video explores the relationship between the drop and the ocean in terms of human experience. While the camera is trained in close up on their eyes, a series of people answer the question, “What is your most significant memory?”

The words and the eyes are played out of sync, so that one person’s voice speaks under another’s gaze. This simple device releases the memories from individual ownership, and the work becomes a gesture towards transcendence. Informed by the Jungian notion of the collective unconscious, The Memory of Water examines the gaze as a bridge between inner and outer worlds.

results.title: Get in the picture at ACMI - Open House 25-7-04
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘In the Picture’ - a free taste of our popular Screen Adventures Program. Members of the public were invited to walk on and act up in front of ACMI’s blue screen ‘film genre’ sets.

results.title: Talks: a Natimuk Primary School animation
results.creator_credit: Dave Jones and Natimuk Primary School
results.brief_description: A collaboration between students from Natimuk Primary School and animation artists Dave Jones funded as part of the Arts Victoria Artists in Schools program. Hand drawn crayon drawings are animated and Combined with recorded soundgrabs from the kids to make an engaging sequence of simple, colourful character studies!

results.title: The Nature of paradise
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Lucinda Gamble
results.brief_description:
Three women - Trish Molloy (artist), Monique La Fontaine (artist), Sharon Wiggan (law student) - tell their stories, each from a personal perspective, of their relationship and connection to the Western Australian north-west coastal town of Broome. Trish and Monique are travellers who have separately found their way to Broome and stayed and Sharon is an Aboriginal Australian who was brought up in Broome, left to study in Perth and who has now returned home to Broome. The documentary explores each woman’s emotional and spiritual attachment to the town, to their surrounding environment and their kinship with the people of Broome and with each other. Evocative and beautifully photographed by Veronica Iacono, and sensitively scripted and directed by Lucinda Gamble, “The Nature of paradise” is stunningly rich in images and colour, of reds and blues, of the earth, sky and the ocean and is accompanied by an ambient musical soundtrack, “Free diving” written and performed by Lorrei
Coffin. Interspersed throughout the documentary are images of both Trish and Monique’s paintings which reflect their transitional journey to this place called “paradise”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Lucinda Gamble
